title: How to Reuse Bacon Grease

steps.headline: Flavor a pot of beans.
steps.description: Nothing like good old bacon smokiness to jazz up a pot of beans. Although eating bacon grease may not be heart healthy (or thigh healthy) it is awfully tasty and cuts down on the amount of salt needed to enhance the bean’s flavor.

steps.headline: Fry potatoes.
steps.description: Whether you are making homemade French fries or whole sliced potatoes, coating the bottom of your pan with bacon grease adds an entirely new dimension of flavor to a humdrum spud.

steps.headline: Enhance your pet’s food with a little bacon grease.
steps.description: Your dog (or cat) will go wild having a little bacon grease drizzled over his kibble. Not only will he love the taste, the grease will add an extra shine to his coat.

steps.headline: Feed birds by coating a pinecone in bacon grease and then roll it in birdseed.
steps.description: Hang from a tree or simply lay on your back porch--if you grease it, they will come!

steps.headline: Heal and soothe small cuts and scrapes with bacon grease.
steps.description: Rub a small amount of cooled grease on a small cut to lubricate and alleviate redness and swelling.

steps.headline: Remove splinters with bacon grease.
steps.description: Clean area first and then rub bacon grease over the splinter and cover with a bandage. Let grease/fat sit on the skin overnight and then remove the bandage the next day. The grease should soften the skin and loosen the splinter. If the splinter is being stubborn, repeat and try again.

steps.headline: Start a campfire.
steps.description:
Without gas or kerosene, starting a campfire can be very challenging. However, if you soak a few paper towels in bacon grease, place them on the wood and light--you’ll have a fire. If you don’t want to soak paper towels, you can soak pinecones ahead of time, place in a large sealable plastic bag and bring camping. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f9\/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f9\/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Make bacon soap using grease and household lye.
steps.description: Combine 4 cups bacon grease with 2 cups of cool water, 4.2 ounces of lye and food coloring. Heat in a large pot and pour into a mold. Allow several hours for it to cool.

steps.headline: Use as a non-toxic degreaser to alleviate squeaky doors and joints.
Make a bacon grease “survival” candle.

text:
Edible Uses Flavor a pot of beans. Nothing like good old bacon smokiness to jazz up a pot of beans. Although eating bacon grease may not be heart healthy (or thigh healthy) it is awfully tasty and cuts down on the amount of salt needed to enhance the bean’s flavor. Fry potatoes. Whether you are making homemade French fries or whole sliced potatoes, coating the bottom of your pan with bacon grease adds an entirely new dimension of flavor to a humdrum spud. Enhance your pet’s food with a little bacon grease. Your dog (or cat) will go wild having a little bacon grease drizzled over his kibble. Not only will he love the taste, the grease will add an extra shine to his coat. Feed birds by coating a pinecone in bacon grease and then roll it in birdseed. Hang from a tree or simply lay on your back porch--if you grease it, they will come! Medical Uses Heal and soothe small cuts and scrapes with bacon grease. Rub a small amount of cooled grease on a small cut to lubricate and alleviate redness and swelling. Remove splinters with bacon grease. Clean area first and then rub bacon grease over the splinter and cover with a bandage. Let grease/fat sit on the skin overnight and then remove the bandage the next day. The grease should soften the skin and loosen the splinter. If the splinter is being stubborn, repeat and try again. Everyday Uses Start a campfire. Without gas or kerosene, starting a campfire can be very challenging. However, if you soak a few paper towels in bacon grease, place them on the wood and light--you’ll have a fire. If you don’t want to soak paper towels, you can soak pinecones ahead of time, place in a large sealable plastic bag and bring camping. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Make bacon soap using grease and household lye. Combine 4 cups bacon grease with 2 cups of cool water, 4.2 ounces of lye and food coloring. Heat in a large pot and pour into a mold. Allow several hours for it to cool. Use as a non-toxic degreaser to alleviate squeaky doors and joints. Make a bacon grease “survival” candle. Pour cooled grease into a small glass cup or bowl with a wick in it.. Tie a cotton string to the middle of a stick or toothpick (depending upon the width of the cup or bowl). You want most of the string to hang into the bacon grease with a small amount sticking up on top. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Lay the toothpick or stick across the top of the jar or cup. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Light the top of the string and allow it to burn. After 15 to 30 minutes the bacon grease becomes a solid. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet3.jpg/v4-459px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet3.jpg/v4-759px-Reuse-Bacon-Grease-Step-10Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}
